newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - US debt volatilities choppy, await data.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - US debt volatilities choppy, await data.

text.p: Implied volatilities for U.S. debt options were mixed in choppy early afternoon trading as underlying instruments plunged from early highs, reversing a two-day rally ahead of Friday's jobs data, traders said.

"After pumping them (volatilities) up yesterday and early this morning on the follow-through strength (of the bond market), on the down move they've taken it back out," said a bond options trader at the Chicago Board of Trade.
December T-bond futures, after gaining some 1-1/2 points Tuesday, rose nearly another point to a high of 113-13/32 in early trade, but soon slid below Tuesday's 112-19/32 close.
Implied volatilities for December and March T-bond futures options were marginally down on the day at 11.8 and 10.3 percent respectively at midsession.

Even though volatilities normally tend to rise when bond prices fall, today's downturn was seen as a first step back to recent trading ranges, traders said. December futures had just broken above key resistance around 112-00 on Tuesday.

There were many 1,000- to 2,000-lot deals today across the yield curve. Among the largest transactions, an investment bank was said to have bought 12,000 contracts of December 108 puts in 10-year T-notes covered against futures.
"It's not surprising going into Friday's numbers," a Eurodollar trader at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said of the market's choppiness. "I think there's a little bit more uncertainty now."
Implied volatility for March eurodollar futures options rose slightly from Tuesday's closes to around 14.2 percent.

Traders positioning themselves for Friday's October U.S. employment report bid up volatilities particularly in the front months because of higher gamma implications. January volatility rose nearly a full point to about 15.2 percent.
Economists polled by Reuters have forecast, on average, an increase of 212,000 in October non-farm payrolls against a decline of 40,000 in September.

The Eurodollar trader noted that the shorter end of the market looked to be in a better shape than the longer end, citing reactions to Labor Secretary Robert Reich's remarks late in the morning that a jobless rate below five percent was possible in the fourth quarter.
"That put new lows in bonds, but we did hold (at previous session lows)," he said.
Among the largest trades in the Eurodollar pit, a Japanese house was seen selling 5,000 contracts of June 94.00 puts.
